awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Process-Specific Topology Optimization for 3D-Printed Hierarchical Composites and Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
A close look at almost any biological structure reveals an elegant and complex hierarchical arrangement of materials at different length scales that imparts desirable mechanical robustness and function to the structure with minimal wasted material. Prior to the development of additive manufacturing technologies, the creation of components with analogous complexity and hierarchy using engineering materials has been prohibitively expensive or entirely impossible. Now, additive manufacturing technologies, which build materials and structures from the ground up using incremental deposition of material, have opened the doors to designing and creating entirely new classes of structures with unprecedented complexity, hierarchy, and performance. However, design tools do not currently exist that can identify the optimal combinations of materials, hierarchy, and shape for any given application, nor do engineers yet understand exactly when, how, and why hierarchy leads to superior performance. This award will improve our understanding of how structural hierarchy in mechanical components leads to superior performance and create a novel method for designing such structures. By generating this knowledge, design engineers will be better able to make decisions about if, when, and how to utilize hierarchy to create stronger, stiffer, lighter, more efficient components for applications ranging from implants, prosthetics, and sporting equipment, to shipping and aerospace. The project includes activities to educate high school students about advanced manufacturing and dissemination of results directly to industry.

This research will focus on fused filament fabrication and direct-ink writing, since these additive technologies are the most widely accessible and have seen rapid recent development in new high strength, lightweight composite feedstocks. The specific scope of the project is comprised of a series of coupled experimental/numerical research tasks. These tasks build from assessing the effects of 3D printing and hierarchy in simple, classic topology optimization benchmark problems to designing, fabricating, and evaluating designs that utilize cellular infill with graded shape and density. By incorporating the unique features that result from material extrusion additive manufacturing (i.e., perimeter, infill, and material anisotropy) into topology optimization schemes, structures will be optimized specifically for the combination of feedstock material and type of hierarchy desired. While additive manufacturing technology has become ubiquitous in schools, universities, and industry, systematic approaches to teach "design for additive manufacturing" require further development. This project will also help address this national imperative through hands-on additive manufacturing and topology optimization demonstrations, industry educational seminars, and outreach programs for underrepresented minorities, women, and persons with disabilities that will inspire the next generation Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project was motivated by the pressing need to better understand how to most effectively utilize topology optimization (TO) schemes in the design of materials and components fabricated using material extrusion additive manufacturing (MEAM). While both MEAM and TO have been used and studied for many years, MEAM brings with it several unique features that precludes a simple define–>optimize–>print process flow. Conventional MEAM technology—fused filament fabrication (FFF)—utilizes thermoplastic feedstock that is melted as it is extruded through the deposition nozzle and then solidifies as it cools in place. This process leads to weak bonds between adjacent deposited beads. Because any given layer of a printed object is comprised of many adjacent beads, the orientation and pattern used to print layers directly influences the strength and stiffness of printed parts in a way that had not typically been accounted for in TO schemes.  The picture gets more complex when composite materials are printed, because the orientation of fibers in the printed beads dictates the anisotropy of the printed material. The amount of anisotropy is influenced by the material composition and the print speed, while the direction of anisotropy is dictated by the arrangement of printed beads used to complete each layer. This kind of information was not usually incorporated in TO tools and strategies for deciding when and how to include it were lacking. Indeed, it is not clear whether printing-related material anisotropy should change the optimal topology for a given load case.

            With this context, this effort has led to several advances in understanding how anisotropy arises and can be controlled in printed composites, how to choose printing approaches that maximize performance of a topologically-optimized structure, and how to design better composite materials for MEAM, along with advances in TO tools that explicitly incorporate the unique features of MEAM. The research supported by this grant has been published in academic journals for broad dissemination among the research community. Key outcomes from select publications are listed below:

“Mechanical anisotropy in polymer composites produced by material extrusion additive manufacturing,” published in Additive Manufacturing, volume 34 (2020): This work established the link between two critical printing parameters—nozzle size and printing speed—and the degree of anisotropy in strength and elastic modulus of polymer composites fabricated using MEAM. Printed epoxy composites containing reinforcements having aspect ratio near unity do not display mechanical anisotropy, whereas those reinforced with high-aspect-ratio fillers, like fibers, display mechanical anisotropy that is a power-law function of the print speed divided by the nozzle diameter. This understanding allows rapid and accurate prediction of the structural properties of a printed composite over a wide range of printing parameters using only a small number of calibration tests.

“Processing and mechanical characterization of short carbon fiber-reinforced epoxy composites for material extrusion additive manufacturing,” published in Composites Part B: Engineering, volume 223 (2021): This study examines how the formulation and mixing of fiber-reinforced feedstocks for MEAM affects the fiber length distribution (FLD), and how the FLD affects printing behavior and mechanical properties. Key results indicate that FLD for carbon fibers can be modeled with a Weibull-type power law distribution function, and that, because fiber orientation increases with increasing print speed, and shorter fibers enable printing at higher translation rates, shorter fibers actually can lead to both better printing and better mechanical properties than a composite of identical composition that has longer fibers. This is not an intuitive result and will help identify optimal processing parameters to maximize mechanical performance in printed composites.

“Effects of infill patterns on the strength and stiffness of 3D printed topologically optimized geometries,” published in Rapid Prototyping Journal, volume 27, issue 8 (2021): This work highlighted the importance of deliberately choosing the slicing parameters in MEAM to most effectively utilize TO schemes. For example, the strength of topology optimized structures depends sensitively on the slicing approach and infill pattern chosen during printing. Best approaches align printing paths with external boundaries and minimize gaps in infill regions.

“Experimental investigations of the effectiveness of simultaneous topology/orientation optimization via SOMP and principal stress directions,” published in Materials and Design, volume 217 (2022): This work developed a new approach to simultaneously optimize topology and fiber orientation in 3D-printed composites to identify whether or not the optimal topology changes due to anisotropy that arises in printed composites. Numerical predictions using this new tool were compared to experimental results using MEAM-printed carbon fiber-reinforced epoxy composites. These comparisons found that equivalent performance can be achieved by either optimizing topology and orientation concurrently, or by first optimizing topology assuming isotropic material properties, then optimizing fiber orientation within the optimized topology. Furthermore, when using MEAM, a concentric print path naturally results in nearly optimal fiber orientation for a given topology, reducing the need for an explicit principal-stress-based calculation of optimal fiber orientation.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2023
Modified by: Natasha Vermaak

This project was motivated by the pressing need to better understand how to most effectively utilize topology optimization (TO) schemes in the design of materials and components fabricated using material extrusion additive manufacturing (MEAM). While both MEAM and TO have been used and studied for many years, MEAM brings with it several unique features that precludes a simple defineoptimizeprint process flow. Conventional MEAM technologyfused filament fabrication (FFF)utilizes thermoplastic feedstock that is melted as it is extruded through the deposition nozzle and then solidifies as it cools in place. This process leads to weak bonds between adjacent deposited beads. Because any given layer of a printed object is comprised of many adjacent beads, the orientation and pattern used to print layers directly influences the strength and stiffness of printed parts in a way that had not typically been accounted for in TO schemes. The amount of anisotropy is influenced by the material composition and the print speed, while the direction of anisotropy is dictated by the arrangement of printed beads used to complete each layer. This kind of information was not usually incorporated in TO tools and strategies for deciding when and how to include it were lacking. Indeed, it is not clear whether printing-related material anisotropy should change the optimal topology for a given load case.


 With this context, this effort has led to several advances in understanding how anisotropy arises and can be controlled in printed composites, how to choose printing approaches that maximize performance of a topologically-optimized structure, and how to design better composite materials for MEAM, along with advances in TO tools that explicitly incorporate the unique features of MEAM. Mechanical anisotropy in polymer composites produced by material extrusion additive manufacturing, published in Additive Manufacturing, volume 34 (2020): This work established the link between two critical printing parametersnozzle size and printing speedand the degree of anisotropy in strength and elastic modulus of polymer composites fabricated using MEAM. Printed epoxy composites containing reinforcements having aspect ratio near unity do not display mechanical anisotropy, whereas those reinforced with high-aspect-ratio fillers, like fibers, display mechanical anisotropy that is a power-law function of the print speed divided by the nozzle diameter. This understanding allows rapid and accurate prediction of the structural properties of a printed composite over a wide range of printing parameters using only a small number of calibration tests.


Processing and mechanical characterization of short carbon fiber-reinforced epoxy composites for material extrusion additive manufacturing, published in Composites Part B: Engineering, volume 223 (2021): This study examines how the formulation and mixing of fiber-reinforced feedstocks for MEAM affects the fiber length distribution (FLD), and how the FLD affects printing behavior and mechanical properties. Key results indicate that FLD for carbon fibers can be modeled with a Weibull-type power law distribution function, and that, because fiber orientation increases with increasing print speed, and shorter fibers enable printing at higher translation rates, shorter fibers actually can lead to both better printing and better mechanical properties than a composite of identical composition that has longer fibers. This is not an intuitive result and will help identify optimal processing parameters to maximize mechanical performance in printed composites.

For example, the strength of topology optimized structures depends sensitively on the slicing approach and infill pattern chosen during printing. Best approaches align printing paths with external boundaries and minimize gaps in infill regions.
